abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings assess the project as
            satisfactory, sustainability as likely, and institutional
            development impact as substantial. Key lessons address the
            following issues. 1) The beneficial impact of long-distance
            trade, was enhanced by the inter-provincial cooperation, an
            ambitious undertaking, but successful due to strong
            preparation, and management, which has subsequently been
            financed in national highways projects. 2) Delays in the
            implementation of electrical, and mechanical systems,
            hindered an optimal operation of assets built under the
            project, (similar to delays under other projects implemented
            during the 1990s); thus stricter control of procurement
            schedules concerning these components, needs to be enforced
            by implementing agencies, and the many central government
            agencies involved in the clearance process. 3) The
            constraints posed by operating the expressway under one
            specific branch of government, hinders the financial
            viability of the project, but in order to enhance
            sustainability, both Hebei and Henan Provinces have agreed
            to take steps for further commercialization of their
            respective expressway management companies. 4) Taking into
            consideration the five main cities along the SAXE corridor,
            coordination of expressway planning, with city plans
            requires further review, including mechanisms to improve
            coordination with municipalities, and the Provincial
            Communications Department.

repnme.cdata!:
China - National Highway (Hebei - Henan)
            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The resettlement plan for the Xinxiang -
            Zhengzhou highway upgrade of the National Highway
            (Hebei-Henan) Project, calls for actions to compensate
            affected populations for loss of land, standing crops, and
            resettlement. In the case of acquisition of sub-urban
            vegetable plots, State regulations require payment from the
            project unit. Compensation fees for cultivated land should
            be based on an estimated annual production value, per an
            average three year period, prior to acquisition, and,
            resettlement grants should at least, maintain the living
            standards of the affected population. Likewise, affected
            collective units must use land compensation, and
            resettlement grants to develop production, and/or create
            jobs, for vulnerable groups. The county land administration
            department, in coordination with the project owner and the
            affected populations, should engage in an effort to provide
            labor, through agricultural production, and township
            enterprise development, under strict land control for
            township construction. In consultation with the affected
            population, the following are avenues of participation in
            the resettlement process: 1) selection of specific
            residential sites for housing locations; 2) choice for
            affected people to either build their own houses, or select
            government built houses; 3) ability to elect employment
            opportunities; and, 4) grievance mechanisms will be
            available, during resettlement implementation.

            Project : resettlement action plan

repnme.cdata!:
China - National Highway Project :
            environmental action plan and impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental action plan and
            impact assessment of a National Highway Project, the
            Shijiazhuang-Anyang Expressway, comprising six
            interconnecting roads. During the planning and design stage,
            potentially negative environmental impacts include:
            reduction of flood discharge ability; removal and
            resettlement of residents in the right of way; loss of land
            resources; and the erosion of roadbed soil caused by
            wastewater from ditches. These will be mitigated
            respectively by rationally selecting alignment; executing a
            reasonable resettlement plan providing suitable
            compensation; restricting the amount of farmland acquired;
            increasing the number of waterspouts, and avoiding the
            waterfall effect by adjusting their positions; and paving
            road surfaces with stone or concrete. During the
            construction stage, potential impacts anticipated are: 1)
            increased river residue caused by litter and erosion in the
            construction site and in the new road; 2) air, water, and
            soil pollution caused by oil, gas, fuel, or paint in
            equipment, asphalt-mixing or cement-mixing stations; 3) dust
            and noise pollution around construction sites; 4) bad
            drainage conditions; and 5) mosquito-breeding conditions,
            such as that caused by still water ponds. These impacts will
            be alleviated by: 1) covering and protecting topsoil with
            green plants; 2) collecting and recycling lubricants to
            avoid spillage and leakage; 3) installing equipment to
            control air pollution, and removing asphalt-mixing equipment
            to safe distances from inhabited areas on the leeward side;
            4) regularly spraying the temporary road with water, and
            installing and setting up sound barriers; 5) building
            suitable toilet facilities; and 6) taking measures to reduce
            mosquito-breeding environments. During the operational
            stage: 1) air pollution will be further reduced by
            controlling vehicle emissions; 2) water pollution caused by
            road runoff into irrigation systems and water sources will
            be avoided; 3) litter processing equipment and appropriate
            legislation will inhibit/prohibit littering; 4) injuries and
            deaths caused by toxic spills and leakages produced by
            transport will be headed off by planning and managing a
            program to reduce such accidents.

docna.cdata!:
China - National Highway Project :
            environmental action plan and impact assessment

display_title.display_title:
China - National Highway Project
            : environmental action plan and impact assessment (Vol. 6)

            construction stage, potential impacts anticipated are: 1)
            increased river residue caused by litter and erosion in the
            construction site and in the new road; 2) air, water, and
            soil pollution caused by oil, gas, fuel, or paint in
            equipment, asphalt-mixing or cement-mixing stations; 3) dust
            and noise pollution around construction sites; 4) bad
            drainage conditions; and 5) mosquito-breeding conditions,
            such as that caused by still water ponds. These impacts will
            be alleviated by: 1) covering and protecting topsoil with
            green plants; 2) collecting and recycling lubricants to
            avoid spillage and leakage; 3) installing equipment to
            control air pollution, and removing asphalt-mixing equipment
            to safe distances from inhabited areas on the leeward side;
            4) regularly spraying the temporary road with water, and
            installing and setting up sound barriers; 5) building
            suitable toilet facilities; and 6) taking measures to reduce
            mosquito-breeding environments. During the operational
            stage: 1) air pollution will be further reduced by
            controlling vehicle emissions; 2) water pollution caused by
            road runoff into irrigation systems and water sources will
            be avoided; 3) litter processing equipment and appropriate
            legislation will inhibit/prohibit littering; 4) injuries and
            deaths caused by toxic spills and leakages produced by
            transport will be headed off by planning and managing a
            program to reduce such accidents.

China - National Highway Project :
            environmental action plan and impact assessment

            : environmental action plan and impact assessment (Vol. 2)

repnme.cdata!:
China - National Highway Project :
            environmental action plan and impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental action plan and
            impact assessment of a National Highway Project, the
            Shijiazhuang-Anyang Expressway, comprising six
            interconnecting roads. During the planning and design stage,
            potentially negative environmental impacts include:
            reduction of flood discharge ability; removal and
            resettlement of residents in the right of way; loss of land
            resources; and the erosion of roadbed soil caused by
            wastewater from ditches. These will be mitigated
            respectively by rationally selecting alignment; executing a
            reasonable resettlement plan providing suitable
            compensation; restricting the amount of farmland acquired;
            increasing the number of waterspouts, and avoiding the
            waterfall effect by adjusting their positions; and paving
            road surfaces with stone or concrete. During the
            construction stage, potential impacts anticipated are: 1)
            increased river residue caused by litter and erosion in the
            construction site and in the new road; 2) air, water, and
            soil pollution caused by oil, gas, fuel, or paint in
            equipment, asphalt-mixing or cement-mixing stations; 3) dust
            and noise pollution around construction sites; 4) bad
            drainage conditions; and 5) mosquito-breeding conditions,
            such as that caused by still water ponds. These impacts will
            be alleviated by: 1) covering and protecting topsoil with
            green plants; 2) collecting and recycling lubricants to
            avoid spillage and leakage; 3) installing equipment to
            control air pollution, and removing asphalt-mixing equipment
            to safe distances from inhabited areas on the leeward side;
            4) regularly spraying the temporary road with water, and
            installing and setting up sound barriers; 5) building
            suitable toilet facilities; and 6) taking measures to reduce
            mosquito-breeding environments. During the operational
            stage: 1) air pollution will be further reduced by
            controlling vehicle emissions; 2) water pollution caused by
            road runoff into irrigation systems and water sources will
            be avoided; 3) litter processing equipment and appropriate
            legislation will inhibit/prohibit littering; 4) injuries and
            deaths caused by toxic spills and leakages produced by
            transport will be headed off by planning and managing a
            program to reduce such accidents.
